L1: import { defineSchema, defineTable } from "convex/server";
L2: import { v } from "convex/values";
L3: 
L4: export default defineSchema({
L5:   threads: defineTable({
L6:     // External ID (UUIDv7) used in URLs
L7:     externalId: v.string(),
L8:     
L9:     title: v.optional(v.string()),
L10:     summary: v.optional(v.string()),
L11:     tags: v.optional(v.array(v.string())),
L12:     userId: v.optional(v.string()),
L13:     
L14:     // Config snapshots
L15:     modelProviderId: v.optional(v.string()),
L16:     modelProviderApi: v.optional(v.string()),
L17:     model: v.optional(v.string()),
L18:     agentRole: v.optional(v.string()),
L19:     
L20:     // Metadata
L21:     createdAt: v.number(),
L22:     updatedAt: v.number(),
L23:   })
L24:   .index("by_externalId", ["externalId"])
L25:   .index("by_userId", ["userId"]),
L26: 
L27:   messages: defineTable({
L28:     threadId: v.id("threads"),
L29:     
L30:     // Role: user, assistant, system
L31:     role: v.string(),
L32:     
L33:     // Content (text)
L34:     content: v.string(),
L35:     
L36:     // Optional: For grouping messages into a "Turn"
L37:     turnId: v.optional(v.string()),
L38:     
L39:     // Type discriminator: "message", "tool_call", "tool_output"
L40:     type: v.optional(v.string()),
L41:     
L42:     // Tool specific fields
L43:     callId: v.optional(v.string()),
L44:     toolName: v.optional(v.string()),
L45:     toolArgs: v.optional(v.any()),
L46:     toolOutput: v.optional(v.any()),
L47:     status: v.optional(v.string()), // succeeded/failed
L48:     
L49:     createdAt: v.number(),
L50:   })
L51:   .index("by_threadId", ["threadId"]),
L52: });

L1: /* eslint-disable */
L2: /**
L3:  * Generated utilities for implementing server-side Convex query and mutation functions.
L4:  *
L5:  * THIS CODE IS AUTOMATICALLY GENERATED.
L6:  *
L7:  * To regenerate, run `npx convex dev`.
L8:  * @module
L9:  */
L10: 
L11: import {
L12:   actionGeneric,
L13:   httpActionGeneric,
L14:   queryGeneric,
L15:   mutationGeneric,
L16:   internalActionGeneric,
L17:   internalMutationGeneric,
L18:   internalQueryGeneric,
L19: } from "convex/server";
L20: 
L21: /**
L22:  * Define a query in this Convex app's public API.
L23:  *
L24:  * This function will be allowed to read your Convex database and will be accessible from the client.
L25:  *
L26:  * @param func - The query function. It receives a {@link QueryCtx} as its first argument.
L27:  * @returns The wrapped query. Include this as an `export` to name it and make it accessible.
L28:  */
L29: export const query = queryGeneric;
L30: 
L31: /**
L32:  * Define a query that is only accessible from other Convex functions (but not from the client).
L33:  *
L34:  * This function will be allowed to read from your Convex database. It will not be accessible from the client.
L35:  *
L36:  * @param func - The query function. It receives a {@link QueryCtx} as its first argument.
L37:  * @returns The wrapped query. Include this as an `export` to name it and make it accessible.
L38:  */
L39: export const internalQuery = internalQueryGeneric;
L40: 
L41: /**
L42:  * Define a mutation in this Convex app's public API.
L43:  *
L44:  * This function will be allowed to modify your Convex database and will be accessible from the client.
L45:  *
L46:  * @param func - The mutation function. It receives a {@link MutationCtx} as its first argument.
L47:  * @returns The wrapped mutation. Include this as an `export` to name it and make it accessible.
L48:  */
L49: export const mutation = mutationGeneric;
L50: 
L51: /**
L52:  * Define a mutation that is only accessible from other Convex functions (but not from the client).
L53:  *
L54:  * This function will be allowed to modify your Convex database. It will not be accessible from the client.
L55:  *
L56:  * @param func - The mutation function. It receives a {@link MutationCtx} as its first argument.
L57:  * @returns The wrapped mutation. Include this as an `export` to name it and make it accessible.
L58:  */
L59: export const internalMutation = internalMutationGeneric;
L60: 
L61: /**
L62:  * Define an action in this Convex app's public API.
L63:  *
L64:  * An action is a function which can execute any JavaScript code, including non-deterministic
L65:  * code and code with side-effects, like calling third-party services.
L66:  * They can be run in Convex's JavaScript environment or in Node.js using the "use node" directive.
L67:  * They can interact with the database indirectly by calling queries and mutations using the {@link ActionCtx}.
L68:  *
L69:  * @param func - The action. It receives an {@link ActionCtx} as its first argument.
L70:  * @returns The wrapped action. Include this as an `export` to name it and make it accessible.
L71:  */
L72: export const action = actionGeneric;
L73: 
L74: /**
L75:  * Define an action that is only accessible from other Convex functions (but not from the client).
L76:  *
L77:  * @param func - The function. It receives an {@link ActionCtx} as its first argument.
L78:  * @returns The wrapped function. Include this as an `export` to name it and make it accessible.
L79:  */
L80: export const internalAction = internalActionGeneric;
L81: 
L82: /**
L83:  * Define an HTTP action.
L84:  *
L85:  * The wrapped function will be used to respond to HTTP requests received
L86:  * by a Convex deployment if the requests matches the path and method where
L87:  * this action is routed. Be sure to route your httpAction in `convex/http.js`.
L88:  *
L89:  * @param func - The function. It receives an {@link ActionCtx} as its first argument
L90:  * and a Fetch API `Request` object as its second.
L91:  * @returns The wrapped function. Import this function from `convex/http.js` and route it to hook it up.
L92:  */
L93: export const httpAction = httpActionGeneric;

L1: # Welcome to your Convex functions directory!
L2: 
L3: Write your Convex functions here.
L4: See https://docs.convex.dev/functions for more.
L5: 
L6: A query function that takes two arguments looks like:
L7: 
L8: ```ts
L9: // convex/myFunctions.ts
L10: import { query } from "./_generated/server";
L11: import { v } from "convex/values";
L12: 
L13: export const myQueryFunction = query({
L14:   // Validators for arguments.
L15:   args: {
L16:     first: v.number(),
L17:     second: v.string(),
L18:   },
L19: 
L20:   // Function implementation.
L21:   handler: async (ctx, args) => {
L22:     // Read the database as many times as you need here.
L23:     // See https://docs.convex.dev/database/reading-data.
L24:     const documents = await ctx.db.query("tablename").collect();
L25: 
L26:     // Arguments passed from the client are properties of the args object.
L27:     console.log(args.first, args.second);
L28: 
L29:     // Write arbitrary JavaScript here: filter, aggregate, build derived data,
L30:     // remove non-public properties, or create new objects.
L31:     return documents;
L32:   },
L33: });
L34: ```
L35: 
L36: Using this query function in a React component looks like:
L37: 
L38: ```ts
L39: const data = useQuery(api.myFunctions.myQueryFunction, {
L40:   first: 10,
L41:   second: "hello",
L42: });
L43: ```
L44: 
L45: A mutation function looks like:
L46: 
L47: ```ts
L48: // convex/myFunctions.ts
L49: import { mutation } from "./_generated/server";
L50: import { v } from "convex/values";
L51: 
L52: export const myMutationFunction = mutation({
L53:   // Validators for arguments.
L54:   args: {
L55:     first: v.string(),
L56:     second: v.string(),
L57:   },
L58: 
L59:   // Function implementation.
L60:   handler: async (ctx, args) => {
L61:     // Insert or modify documents in the database here.
L62:     // Mutations can also read from the database like queries.
L63:     // See https://docs.convex.dev/database/writing-data.
L64:     const message = { body: args.first, author: args.second };
L65:     const id = await ctx.db.insert("messages", message);
L66: 
L67:     // Optionally, return a value from your mutation.
L68:     return await ctx.db.get(id);
L69:   },
L70: });
L71: ```
L72: 
L73: Using this mutation function in a React component looks like:
L74: 
L75: ```ts
L76: const mutation = useMutation(api.myFunctions.myMutationFunction);
L77: function handleButtonPress() {
L78:   // fire and forget, the most common way to use mutations
L79:   mutation({ first: "Hello!", second: "me" });
L80:   // OR
L81:   // use the result once the mutation has completed
L82:   mutation({ first: "Hello!", second: "me" }).then((result) =>
L83:     console.log(result),
L84:   );
L85: }
L86: ```
L87: 
L88: Use the Convex CLI to push your functions to a deployment. See everything
L89: the Convex CLI can do by running `npx convex -h` in your project root
L90: directory. To learn more, launch the docs with `npx convex docs`.

data.message:
Done — I ran the commands you requested and inspected the Convex functions. Outputs and a summary follow.

Command outputs
- pwd
  - /Users/leemoore/code/codex-port-02/cody-fastify

- ls (top-level)
  - Important entries (truncated): .env, README.md, convex/ (directory), node_modules/, package.json, src/, tests/, tsconfig.json

- ls convex
  - README.md
  - _generated/  (contains generated types/utilities)
  - messages.ts
  - schema.ts
  - threads.ts
  - tsconfig.json

Files I read and what they do
1) convex/schema.ts
- Defines the Convex schema with two tables:
  - threads:
    - Fields: externalId (string), title, summary, tags, userId, modelProviderId, modelProviderApi, model, agentRole, createdAt, updatedAt.
    - Indexes: by_externalId (externalId), by_userId (userId).
    - externalId is used as an external UUID for URLs.
  - messages:
    - Fields: threadId (id referencing threads), role (user/assistant/system), content (string), optional turnId, optional type (message / tool_call / tool_output), optional callId, toolName, toolArgs, toolOutput, status, createdAt.
    - Index: by_threadId.
- Overall: schema models conversation threads and the messages within them, with fields to support tool calls and metadata.

2) convex/threads.ts
- Exposes several Convex functions (queries and mutations) for threads:
  - create (mutation): inserts a new thread with externalId, model/provider snapshot fields, title/summary/tags, agentRole, sets createdAt and updatedAt and returns the inserted id.
  - get (query): fetch a thread by externalId using the by_externalId index.
  - list (query): list threads ordered desc with pagination (uses paginationOptsValidator from convex/server).
  - update (mutation): patch thread fields (title, model, summary, tags, agentRole, modelProviderId/Api) and sets updatedAt.
  - remove (mutation): delete a thread by externalId (finds thread via index and deletes).
  - clearAll (mutation): internal/testing helper that deletes all threads and messages (loops and deletes).
- Notes: timestamps are numeric (Date.now()).

3) convex/messages.ts
- Exposes functions for messages:
  - add (mutation): takes conversationId (maps to thread.externalId), role, content and optional turnId, type, callId, toolName, toolArgs, toolOutput, status. It:
    - Looks up the thread by externalId (index by_externalId).
    - Inserts a message document pointing to threadId with createdAt timestamp.
    - Touches the thread's updatedAt (ctx.db.patch) so thread update time is advanced when messages are added.
  - list (query): lists messages for a thread by threadId using by_threadId index and returns collected messages.
- Notes: supports tooling metadata on messages (toolName, args, output, status) enabling tool-call / tool-output tracking.

4) convex/_generated
- Contains auto-generated files (api.d.ts, api.js, dataModel.d.ts, server.d.ts, server.js).
- server.js is the generated helper that wraps query/mutation/action functions (it exports query, mutation, internalQuery, action, etc.). It is generated by Convex (npx convex dev) and used by the .ts files to declare their functions.

5) convex/README.md and tsconfig.json
- convext/README.md: standard template for Convex functions.
- tsconfig.json: TypeScript config for Convex functions (not inspected in detail).

High-level overview: how Convex is being used in this project
- Convex is used as the backend data layer for a conversation system.
- Data model: There are two main collections:
  - threads — top-level conversation metadata and config snapshots (model/provider info, tags, title, timestamps).
  - messages — individual messages linked to a thread (role, content, grouping turnId, and rich tool-call metadata).
- API surface:
  - Thread-related mutations/queries: create/get/list/update/remove and a test helper clearAll.
  - Message-related mutations/queries: add a message (by external thread id) and list messages by thread id.
- Additional behavior:
  - Threads are looked up by an externalId (UUID) used externally (likely in URLs).
  - When messages are added, the thread.updatedAt is touched so thread listing/order/last-activity is accurate.
  - Messages store tool call metadata (callId, toolName, toolArgs, toolOutput, status), so the app can track external tool usage per message/turn.
  - Pagination is supported when listing threads (paginationOptsValidator).
- Generated helpers in _generated provide typed wrappers for defining queries/mutations and are produced by the Convex toolchain.

If you want, I can:
- Search the rest of the codebase (src/) to show where these Convex functions are called from the app,
- Inspect the _generated TypeScript definitions to show typed function signatures,
- Or open any of these files and show specific function contents/lines.

content.text: run a pwd to verify which directory you are in. in one tool call. then run ls to see the subdirectories 1 in the next tool call. then navigate to the convex directory in another tool call then list the files in the convex directory in another tool call, then read each file and give me an overview of how convex is being used

summary.text:
**Running command sequence**

I need to run commands using the exec tool in sequence. First, I’ll run `pwd` to check the current directory. Next, I’ll run `ls` to list files. Then, I have to navigate to the convex directory with a `cd convex` command, which is separate because of the instructions given. After that, I’ll list the files in the convex directory with another `ls` command. It’s interesting to note that the working directory won't persist across commands unless I specify the cwd parameter.

**Following user sequence**

The user requested a specific sequence of commands: first, I need to run `pwd` in one tool call. Next, I'll execute `ls` to view the subdirectories in another call. After that, I need to navigate to the convex directory with an additional command and then list the files there in a separate call. To do this, I can use `cd convex && pwd` for navigation. Finally, I’ll run `ls -la` to get the files in the convex directory. It’s essential to stick to these instructions!

**Implementing command sequence**

To strictly follow the user's instructions, I need to run `cd convex && pwd` in the navigation call. They want distinct commands for navigating and listing files, so I’ll first navigate with `cd convex && pwd`. Then, I’ll list the files with either `ls -la` using the cwd parameter set to convex or by running `ls -la convex`. After that, I'll read each file using the readFile tool based on the list generated. Now, I'll start by executing `pwd` to set the stage!

L1: import { defineSchema, defineTable } from "convex/server";
L2: import { v } from "convex/values";
L3: 
L4: export default defineSchema({
L5:   threads: defineTable({
L6:     // External ID (UUIDv7) used in URLs
L7:     externalId: v.string(),
L8:     
L9:     title: v.optional(v.string()),
L10:     summary: v.optional(v.string()),
L11:     tags: v.optional(v.array(v.string())),
L12:     userId: v.optional(v.string()),
L13:     
L14:     // Config snapshots
L15:     modelProviderId: v.optional(v.string()),
L16:     modelProviderApi: v.optional(v.string()),
L17:     model: v.optional(v.string()),
L18:     agentRole: v.optional(v.string()),
L19:     
L20:     // Metadata
L21:     createdAt: v.number(),
L22:     updatedAt: v.number(),
L23:   })
L24:   .index("by_externalId", ["externalId"])
L25:   .index("by_userId", ["userId"]),
L26: 
L27:   messages: defineTable({
L28:     threadId: v.id("threads"),
L29:     
L30:     // Role: user, assistant, system
L31:     role: v.string(),
L32:     
L33:     // Content (text)
L34:     content: v.string(),
L35:     
L36:     // Optional: For grouping messages into a "Turn"
L37:     turnId: v.optional(v.string()),
L38:     
L39:     // Type discriminator: "message", "tool_call", "tool_output"
L40:     type: v.optional(v.string()),
L41:     
L42:     // Tool specific fields
L43:     callId: v.optional(v.string()),
L44:     toolName: v.optional(v.string()),
L45:     toolArgs: v.optional(v.any()),
L46:     toolOutput: v.optional(v.any()),
L47:     status: v.optional(v.string()), // succeeded/failed
L48:     
L49:     createdAt: v.number(),
L50:   })
L51:   .index("by_threadId", ["threadId"]),
L52: });

L1: # Welcome to your Convex functions directory!
L2: 
L3: Write your Convex functions here.
L4: See https://docs.convex.dev/functions for more.
L5: 
L6: A query function that takes two arguments looks like:
L7: 
L8: ```ts
L9: // convex/myFunctions.ts
L10: import { query } from "./_generated/server";
L11: import { v } from "convex/values";
L12: 
L13: export const myQueryFunction = query({
L14:   // Validators for arguments.
L15:   args: {
L16:     first: v.number(),
L17:     second: v.string(),
L18:   },
L19: 
L20:   // Function implementation.
L21:   handler: async (ctx, args) => {
L22:     // Read the database as many times as you need here.
L23:     // See https://docs.convex.dev/database/reading-data.
L24:     const documents = await ctx.db.query("tablename").collect();
L25: 
L26:     // Arguments passed from the client are properties of the args object.
L27:     console.log(args.first, args.second);
L28: 
L29:     // Write arbitrary JavaScript here: filter, aggregate, build derived data,
L30:     // remove non-public properties, or create new objects.
L31:     return documents;
L32:   },
L33: });
L34: ```
L35: 
L36: Using this query function in a React component looks like:
L37: 
L38: ```ts
L39: const data = useQuery(api.myFunctions.myQueryFunction, {
L40:   first: 10,
L41:   second: "hello",
L42: });
L43: ```
L44: 
L45: A mutation function looks like:
L46: 
L47: ```ts
L48: // convex/myFunctions.ts
L49: import { mutation } from "./_generated/server";
L50: import { v } from "convex/values";
L51: 
L52: export const myMutationFunction = mutation({
L53:   // Validators for arguments.
L54:   args: {
L55:     first: v.string(),
L56:     second: v.string(),
L57:   },
L58: 
L59:   // Function implementation.
L60:   handler: async (ctx, args) => {
L61:     // Insert or modify documents in the database here.
L62:     // Mutations can also read from the database like queries.
L63:     // See https://docs.convex.dev/database/writing-data.
L64:     const message = { body: args.first, author: args.second };
L65:     const id = await ctx.db.insert("messages", message);
L66: 
L67:     // Optionally, return a value from your mutation.
L68:     return await ctx.db.get(id);
L69:   },
L70: });
L71: ```
L72: 
L73: Using this mutation function in a React component looks like:
L74: 
L75: ```ts
L76: const mutation = useMutation(api.myFunctions.myMutationFunction);
L77: function handleButtonPress() {
L78:   // fire and forget, the most common way to use mutations
L79:   mutation({ first: "Hello!", second: "me" });
L80:   // OR
L81:   // use the result once the mutation has completed
L82:   mutation({ first: "Hello!", second: "me" }).then((result) =>
L83:     console.log(result),
L84:   );
L85: }
L86: ```
L87: 
L88: Use the Convex CLI to push your functions to a deployment. See everything
L89: the Convex CLI can do by running `npx convex -h` in your project root
L90: directory. To learn more, launch the docs with `npx convex docs`.

content.text:
Done — I ran the commands you requested and inspected the Convex functions. Outputs and a summary follow.

Command outputs
- pwd
  - /Users/leemoore/code/codex-port-02/cody-fastify

- ls (top-level)
  - Important entries (truncated): .env, README.md, convex/ (directory), node_modules/, package.json, src/, tests/, tsconfig.json

- ls convex
  - README.md
  - _generated/  (contains generated types/utilities)
  - messages.ts
  - schema.ts
  - threads.ts
  - tsconfig.json

Files I read and what they do
1) convex/schema.ts
- Defines the Convex schema with two tables:
  - threads:
    - Fields: externalId (string), title, summary, tags, userId, modelProviderId, modelProviderApi, model, agentRole, createdAt, updatedAt.
    - Indexes: by_externalId (externalId), by_userId (userId).
    - externalId is used as an external UUID for URLs.
  - messages:
    - Fields: threadId (id referencing threads), role (user/assistant/system), content (string), optional turnId, optional type (message / tool_call / tool_output), optional callId, toolName, toolArgs, toolOutput, status, createdAt.
    - Index: by_threadId.
- Overall: schema models conversation threads and the messages within them, with fields to support tool calls and metadata.

2) convex/threads.ts
- Exposes several Convex functions (queries and mutations) for threads:
  - create (mutation): inserts a new thread with externalId, model/provider snapshot fields, title/summary/tags, agentRole, sets createdAt and updatedAt and returns the inserted id.
  - get (query): fetch a thread by externalId using the by_externalId index.
  - list (query): list threads ordered desc with pagination (uses paginationOptsValidator from convex/server).
  - update (mutation): patch thread fields (title, model, summary, tags, agentRole, modelProviderId/Api) and sets updatedAt.
  - remove (mutation): delete a thread by externalId (finds thread via index and deletes).
  - clearAll (mutation): internal/testing helper that deletes all threads and messages (loops and deletes).
- Notes: timestamps are numeric (Date.now()).

3) convex/messages.ts
- Exposes functions for messages:
  - add (mutation): takes conversationId (maps to thread.externalId), role, content and optional turnId, type, callId, toolName, toolArgs, toolOutput, status. It:
    - Looks up the thread by externalId (index by_externalId).
    - Inserts a message document pointing to threadId with createdAt timestamp.
    - Touches the thread's updatedAt (ctx.db.patch) so thread update time is advanced when messages are added.
  - list (query): lists messages for a thread by threadId using by_threadId index and returns collected messages.
- Notes: supports tooling metadata on messages (toolName, args, output, status) enabling tool-call / tool-output tracking.

4) convex/_generated
- Contains auto-generated files (api.d.ts, api.js, dataModel.d.ts, server.d.ts, server.js).
- server.js is the generated helper that wraps query/mutation/action functions (it exports query, mutation, internalQuery, action, etc.). It is generated by Convex (npx convex dev) and used by the .ts files to declare their functions.

5) convex/README.md and tsconfig.json
- convext/README.md: standard template for Convex functions.
- tsconfig.json: TypeScript config for Convex functions (not inspected in detail).

High-level overview: how Convex is being used in this project
- Convex is used as the backend data layer for a conversation system.
- Data model: There are two main collections:
  - threads — top-level conversation metadata and config snapshots (model/provider info, tags, title, timestamps).
  - messages — individual messages linked to a thread (role, content, grouping turnId, and rich tool-call metadata).
- API surface:
  - Thread-related mutations/queries: create/get/list/update/remove and a test helper clearAll.
  - Message-related mutations/queries: add a message (by external thread id) and list messages by thread id.
- Additional behavior:
  - Threads are looked up by an externalId (UUID) used externally (likely in URLs).
  - When messages are added, the thread.updatedAt is touched so thread listing/order/last-activity is accurate.
  - Messages store tool call metadata (callId, toolName, toolArgs, toolOutput, status), so the app can track external tool usage per message/turn.
  - Pagination is supported when listing threads (paginationOptsValidator).
- Generated helpers in _generated provide typed wrappers for defining queries/mutations and are produced by the Convex toolchain.

If you want, I can:
- Search the rest of the codebase (src/) to show where these Convex functions are called from the app,
- Inspect the _generated TypeScript definitions to show typed function signatures,
- Or open any of these files and show specific function contents/lines.
